Description: Scarab carved from steatite; back with clypeus simply indicated, elytra and prothorax marked by double-incised lines; at sige, legs rather well-shaped with undercut trianglular space between front and back legs; underside crudely incised with a stylised beetle between two lenticular vertical patterns (very stylized uraei?); pierced lengthways; in beige steatite, slightly greyish in colour.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Scarab Factory (according to museum register)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by City Art Gallery and Museum, Bristol. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This is one of the early scarabs in stone illustrated by Petrie (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVIII, 168). The presence of such an early type of scarab in Naukratis can be interpreted in many ways: heirloom, brought from a nearby site in antiquity or by sebakhin, archaizing copy of the 25th or 26th dynasty… (on the various early scarabs from Naukratis see: Masson forthcoming). Masson, A. forthcoming, ‘Egyptian Naukratis: the early evidence’, in A. Wodzińska (ed.), Delta and Sinai Current research, Proceedings of the conference in the University of Warsaw, Warsaw, April 25-27 2013. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I., 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVIII, no. 168)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OA.33) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: City Art Gallery and Museum, Bristol
